facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 26 of 1956 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 26 of 1956. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd

facts.text: Appeal is from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd April 1954 of Rajasthan High Court in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 26 of 1956. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd April, 1954, of the Rajasthan High Court in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1951.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J. on August 31, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This is an appeal with the special leave of this Court against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan dated April 22, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant is a private limited Company incorporated in 1945 in the former Kotah State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a private limited Company, which was incorporated in 1945 in the former Kotah State. The income-tax authorities sought to tax its profits and income for the assessment year 1950-51 corresponding to the previous year, 1949-50.

facts.text: Income-tax authorities sought to tax appellant's profits and income for assessment year 1950-51 corresponding to previous year 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax authorities sought to tax its profits and income for the assessment year 1950-51 corresponding to the previous year, 1949-50. The appellant claimed exemption under s. 14(2)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood before the amendment in 1953, contending that the exemption stood good even after the amendment.

facts.text: Appellant claimed exemption under s. 14(2)(c) of Indian Income-tax Act 1922 as before 1953 amendment, contending exemption stood good even after amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed exemption under s. 14(2)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood before the amendment in 1953, contending that the exemption stood good even after the amendment. This claim was rejected by the High Court, which was moved under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's claim under Art. 226 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was rejected by the High Court, which was moved under Art. 226 of the Constitution. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: Prior to integration of Kotah State into United State of Rajasthan in 1949, no income-tax law in force in Kotah State.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the integration of Kotah State into the United State of Rajasthan in 1949, there was no income-tax law in force in Kotah State.

facts.text: Till formation of State of Rajasthan, no income-tax law in force in any part of Rajasthan except Bundi State.

anchor.surface_text: Till the formation of the State of Rajasthan, there was no such law in force in any part of Rajasthan, except Bundi State.

facts.text: Indian Finance Act of 1950 made Indian Income-tax Act 1922 applicable to whole of India except Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Finance Act of 1950 made the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, applicable to the whole of India, except the State of Jammu and Kashmir, and suitably amended the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Rajasthan became taxable territory from April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Rajasthan then became, from April 1, 1950, a taxable territory.

facts.text: Income-tax sought to be imposed in Rajasthan for assessment year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1950-51, income-tax was sought to be imposed in the State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Madan Gopal Kabra moved High Court under Art. 226 to restrain taxing authorities from claiming tax for period prior to April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: One Madan Gopal Kabra move the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution to restrain the taxing authorities from claiming tax for the period prior to April 1, 1950, contending that inasmuch as Rajasthan was not a taxable territory before April 1, 1950, no tax for a period prior to that date could be demanded.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court accepted Madan Gopal Kabra's contention.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in an appeal by the Department against the decision of the High Court of Rajasthan, which had accepted the contention, held that the tax was leviable.

facts.text: Supreme Court held tax was leviable in Union of India v. Madan Gopal Kabra.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in an appeal by the Department against the decision of the High Court of Rajasthan, which had accepted the contention, held that the tax was leviable. It is not necessary to give the details of the decision on that occasion. The judgment of this Court is reported in The Union of India v. Madan Gopal Kabra.

facts.text: Present appellant and fourteen others filed petitions under Art. 226 urging exemption under s.14(2)(c) as on April 1, 1950 not affected by 1953 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The present appellant and fourteen others filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution, urging fresh grounds by a later amendment. Their contention was that s. 14(2)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act, as it stood on April 1, 1950, granted an exemption, and that this exemption was not affected by the amendment of the said provision in 1953 even though the amendment was retrospective from April 1, 1950, unless the Finance Act, 1950, which applied the Income-tax Act to this area was also amended.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court dismissed the Art. 226 petition holding point decided against Madan Gopal Kabra.

anchor.surface_text: This contention was not accepted by the High Court which dismissed the petition under Art. 226, holding inter alia that this point was also decided by this Court against Madan Gopal Kabra.

facts.text: Section 14(2)(c) of Indian Income-tax Act before 1953 amendment exempted income accruing in Part B State unless received or brought into taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14(2)(c), as it stood before the amendment in 1953, read as follows The tax shall not be payable by an assessee-- (c) in respect of any income, profits or gains accruing or arising to him within Part B State unless such income, profits or gains are received or deemed to be received in or are brought into the taxable territories in the previous year by or on behalf of the assessee, or are assessable under section 12-B or section 42.

facts.text: 1953 Amendment to s.14(2)(c) substituted 'Part B State' with 'the State of Jammu and Kashmir' deemed from April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The amendment provided In section 14 of the principal Act in clause (c) of sub- section (2), for the words and letter 'Part B State' the words 'the State of Jammu and Kashmir' shall be substituted and shall be deemed to have been substituted with effect from the 1st day of April, 1950.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Kabra case stated exemption under s.14(2)(c) for Part B States abrogated except J&K from April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The result of this amendment was described by this Court in Kabras case to be as follows It may be mentioned here that the exemption from tax under s. 14(2)(c) of the Indian Act of income accruing within Part B States was abrogated, except as regards the State of Jammu and Kashmir, by the amendment of that provision with effect from the first day of April, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant contends point not finally decided in Kabra case and remark descriptive only.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee appearing for the appellant contends that the point cannot be considered to have been finally decided, and that the remark is descriptive only of what the Parliament had purported to do.

facts.text: Appellant argues Indian Finance Act 1950 incorporated Income-tax Act by reference, subsequent amendments have no effect unless Finance Act amended.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his contention, he urges that the effect of the passing of the Indian Finance Act, 1950, and the application of the Indian Income-tax Act to Rajasthan and other Part B States was to incorporate the Indian Income-tax Act by reference in the Indian Finance Act with such modifications and amendments as were then made.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds both arguments lack substance.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both the arguments have no substance, and the position indicated by this Court in the passage cited earlier, represents the true state of the law.

facts.text: Exemption relates to liability in assessment year 1950-51 regarding income of previous year 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, the exemption is in respect of liability to tax in any year of assessment, and the exemption in the assessment year 1950-51 was in regard to the income in the previous year. For the same reason, the withdrawal of the exemption in the assessment year 1950-51 adversely affected the income of the previous year, 1949-50 which is the subject- matter of tax in this case.

facts.text: Indian Finance Act 1950 applied Income-tax Act but did not incorporate it by reference.

anchor.surface_text: The next argument misconceives the nature of the Indian Finance Act, 1950. By that Act, the Indian Income-tax Act was applied, but the Income-tax Act was not incorporated by reference in the Indian Finance Act to become a part of it.

This is an appeal with the special leave of this Court against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan dated April 22, 1954.
This claim was rejected by the High Court, which was moved under Art. 226 of the Constitution. Hence this appeal.

issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to exemption under section 14(2)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood before the 1953 amendment, for the assessment year 1950-51 corresponding to the previous year 1949-50

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed exemption under s. 14 2  c  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood before the amendment in 1953, companytending that the exemption stood good even after the amendment. This claim was rejected by the High Court, which was moved under Art. 226 of the Constitution. Hence this appeal.

issues.text: Whether the point regarding the effect of the 1953 amendment on the exemption under section 14(2)(c) was already decided in Union of India v. Madan Gopal Kabra and not open for reconsideration

anchor.surface_text: High Court which dismissed the petition under Art. 226, holding inter alia that this point was also decided by this Court against Madan Gopal Kabra. In this appeal, this point alone is argued, and it is contended that the point is still open for decision.

issues.text: Whether the Indian Finance Act, 1950 incorporated the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 by reference such that subsequent amendments to the Income-tax Act in 1953 did not apply unless the Finance Act was also amended

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention, be urges that the effect of the passing of the Indian Finance Act, 1950, and the application of the Indian Income-tax Act to Rajasthan and other Part B States was to incorporate the Indian Income-tax Act by reference in the Indian Finance Act with such modifications and amendments as were then made. Any subsequent amendment of the Indian Income-tax Act had number effect on the original Act as incorporated by reference in the Indian Finance Act, unless the latter was suitably amended also.

issues.text: Whether the 1953 retrospective amendment to section 14(2)(c) withdrawing exemption from April 1, 1950 exempted income accrued prior to April 1, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The argument which did number find favour in Kabras case 1 was again advanced, though in another form. It is that the amendment operates from April 1, 1950, and that the income accrued prior to April 1, 1950, and it was still exempt, because the exemption was withdrawn only from April 1, 1950.

arguments.claim: Both petitioner arguments lack substance; position stated in Kabra case represents true state of law

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both the arguments have no substance, and the position indicated by this Court in the passage cited earlier, represents the true state of the law.

arguments.claim: Exemption under s.14(2)(c) relates to tax liability in assessment year, so 1953 withdrawal for 1950-51 assessment affects 1949-50 previous year income

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, the exemption is in respect of liability to tax in any year of assessment, and the exemption in the assessment year 1950-51 was in regard to the income in the previous year. For the same reason, the withdrawal of the exemption in the assessment year 1950-51 adversely affected the income of the previous year, 1949-50 which is the subject- matter of tax in this case.

arguments.claim: Indian Finance Act 1950 applied Income-tax Act to Rajasthan making it taxable territory but did not incorporate it by reference; subsequent amendments apply

anchor.surface_text: The next argument misconceives the nature of the Indian Finance Act, 1950. By that Act, the Indian Income-tax Act was applied, but the Income-tax Act was not incorporated by reference in the Indian Finance Act to become a part of it. The application of the Indian Income-tax Act made Rajasthan a taxable territory subject to the Indian Income-tax law, and Parliament was competent to enact a new law for the area, just as it did for the whole of the rest of India.

arguments.claim: Deeming fiction in 1953 amendment obliterates s.14(2)(c) exemption as if never granted from April 1, 1950 with no saving clause

anchor.surface_text: The fiction in the amendment made the exemption to disappear as if it had never been granted, and unless there was a saving, the amendment must operate to obliterate the exemption. in fact, the whole purpose and intent of the amendment was to reach this result from the assessment year 1950-51 onwards, and there could be no saving.

arguments.claim: No premise or precedent that applying one Act to territory incorporates it by reference into applying Act

holdings.text: both the arguments have no substance, and the position indicated by this Court in the passage cited earlier, represents the true state of the law

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both the arguments have no substance, and the position indicated by this Court in the passage cited earlier, represents the true state of the law.

By that Act, the Indian Income-tax Act was applied, but the Income-tax Act was not incorporated by reference in the Indian Finance Act to become a part of it. holdings.reasoning_summary: Finance Act 1950 extended application of Income-tax Act to new territory without incorporation by reference allowing subsequent amendments to apply

holdings.text: The fiction in the amendment made the exemption to disappear as if it had never been granted, and unless there was a saving, the amendment must operate to obliterate the exemption. in fact, the whole purpose and intent of the amendment was to reach this result from the assessment year 1950-51 onwards, and there could be no saving

anchor.surface_text: The fiction in the amendment made the exemption to disappear as if it had never been granted, and unless there was a saving, the amendment must operate to obliterate the exemption. in fact, the whole purpose and intent of the amendment was to reach this result from the assessment year 1950-51 onwards, and there could be no saving.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming provision of 1953 amendment retrospectively substitutes words obliterating exemption for Part B States other than J&K from April 1 1950 without saving clause

holdings.text: there is neither precedent nor warrant for the assumption that when one Act applies another Act to some territory, the latter Act must be taken to be incorporated in the former Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal basis or precedent supports incorporation by reference merely from territorial application of one Act by another

holdings.text: the Indian Parliament could amend the Income-tax Act retrospectively, and the amendment would apply also to the new taxable territory. In our opinion, both the arguments are not valid
holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-application of Income-tax Act to Rajasthan, Parliament retained power to retrospectively amend it with effect in new territory

anchor.surface_text: The next argument misconceives the nature of the Indian Finance Act, 1950. By that Act, the Indian Income-tax Act was applied, but the Income-tax Act was not incorporated by reference in the Indian Finance Act to become a part of it. The application of the Indian Income-tax Act made Rajasthan a taxable territory subject to the Indian Income-tax law, and Parliament was competent to enact a new law for the area, just as it did for the whole of the rest of India.
In our opinion, both the arguments are number valid.

The fiction in the amendment made the exemption to disappear as if it had never been granted, and unless there was a saving, the amendment must operate to obliterate the exemption. in fact, the whole purpose and intent of the amendment was to reach this result from the assessment year 1950-51 onwards, and there could be no saving.
In our opinion, both the arguments are number valid.
